head.title: Here Are the New York Enemies of Clean Air

hedline.hl1: Here Are the New York Enemies of Clean Air

block.p: In ''Clean Air Still Beyond Reach'' (editorial, Aug. 15), you take Senator Robert Byrd and Representative John Dingell to task for throttling clean air reauthorization.

Senator Byrd is blocking acid-rain legislation to put dollars for the coal-mining industry of West Virginia ahead of the health of all Americans (and Canadians). Representative Dingell is guilty of the same for the benefit of the automobile industry of Michigan.

But there are four New York legislators who have steadfastly refused to support this legislation. Just four. Three of them are Representatives Thomas Manton of Queens and Edolphus Townes of Brooklyn, both Democrats, and Jack Kemp, Erie County Republican.

Worst of all, Representative Norman Lent, Long Island Republican, the ranking minority member of Mr. Dingell's committee has joined his chairman, forming an alliance to bottle up the clean air bill in committee, thus thwarting the will of the House majority and public opinion across the country.

All other New York representatives have signed the Vento-Green letter (initiated by Representatives Bruce Vento and Bill Green), urging Congress to take strong action on clean air. Indeed, a majority of Congress, 218 members, has signed the letter assuring House passage if Representatives Dingell and Lent let it out of committee.

When New York is threatened by smog, acid rain and ozone depletion, opposition to this bill is contemptuous of public concern. ALVIN HAUSER Syosset, L.I., Aug. 19, 1988 The writer is vice-chairman of the Sierra Club's Long Island group.
